Regulation Title: FINRA Rule on Financial Exploitation of Specified Adults
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 2165, which permits member firms to place temporary holds on disbursements of funds or securities from the accounts of specified adults persons aged 65+ or with a mental or physical impairment where the firm reasonably believes financial exploitation is occurring.
Impact: Provided a critical tool for financial firms to intervene and protect vulnerable investors from potential fraud and exploitation, representing a major step forward in senior investor protection.

Regulation Title: Investment Company Liquidity Risk Management Programs
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 22e4, requiring openend funds including mutual funds and ETFs to establish formal liquidity risk management programs. The programs require funds to assess and manage their liquidity risk, classify the liquidity of their portfolio investments, and establish a "highly liquid investment minimum."
Impact: Aims to ensure funds can meet shareholder redemption requests without diluting the interests of remaining shareholders, especially during times of market stress. It standardized industry practices for managing liquidity.

Regulation Title: Investment Company Reporting Modernization
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted new forms NPORT and NCEN requiring mutual funds, ETFs, and other registered investment companies to report enhanced, standardized, and more frequent portfolio and census data to the SEC.
Impact: Modernized fund reporting and improved the quality of data available to the SEC for oversight, risk monitoring, and policymaking.

Regulation Title: Covered Clearing Agency Standards Recovery and WindDown
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 17Ad22e, which established enhanced standards for systemically important clearing agencies. A key component requires these clearinghouses to maintain and test comprehensive recovery and winddown plans to manage potential failure and minimize systemic disruption.
Impact: Strengthened the resilience of critical financial market infrastructure by ensuring that the largest clearinghouses have credible plans to manage extreme stress or their own potential collapse without taxpayer support.

Regulation Title: Pay Versus Performance
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented a DoddFrank mandate requiring companies to disclose in a clear, tabular format the relationship between executive compensation actually paid and the company's financial performance.
Impact: Provides shareholders with a standardized metric to assess how well executive pay aligns with company performance, improving transparency in compensation decisions.

Regulation Title: MSRB "PaytoPlay" Rule Rule G37
Regulatory Body: Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board MSRB / Approved by SEC
Description: This major overhaul of the existing rule seeks to end "paytoplay" practices in the municipal securities market. It prohibits municipal securities dealers from engaging in municipal securities business with an issuer for two years after making a political contribution to an official of that issuer.
Impact: Aims to sever the connection between political contributions and the awarding of municipal bond underwriting business, thereby reducing corruption and ensuring a meritbased selection of underwriters.

Regulation Title: TradeBased Manipulation Rules
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted rules to apply existing antifraud and antimanipulation provisions to securitybased swaps.
Impact: Extended key market protections to the securitybased swaps market to prevent misconduct and protect market integrity.

Regulation Title: SEC Rule on Risk Mitigation Techniques for Uncleared SecurityBased Swaps
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires securitybased swap dealers to establish and enforce policies for reconciling portfolios with counterparties, compressing portfolios, and executing written trading relationship documentation.
Impact: Complements margin requirements by establishing operational standards that reduce risk and improve efficiency in the uncleared securitybased swap market.

Regulation Title: FINRA Capital Acquisition Broker CAB Rules
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: Created a new, streamlined set of FINRA rules for member firms that engage in a limited range of activities, such as advising on mergers and acquisitions, private placements, or corporate financing. These firms have reduced compliance obligations compared to fullservice brokerdealers.
Impact: Provided a more tailored and less burdensome regulatory framework for advisoryfocused firms, potentially lowering barriers to entry and reducing compliance costs for this segment of the industry.

Regulation Title: Business Conduct Standards for SecurityBased Swap Dealers
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Established a set of rules under DoddFrank governing the conduct of SecurityBased Swap Dealers SBSDs and Major SecurityBased Swap Participants MSBSPs. The rules require fair dealing, disclosure of material information risks, conflicts, and establishing a supervisory structure.
Impact: Created a new regulatory regime for the business conduct of swap dealers, providing protections for their counterparties similar to those that exist in traditional securities markets.

Regulation Title: MSRB Best Execution Rule Rule G18
Regulatory Body: Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board MSRB / Approved by SEC
Description: Formally applied the duty of "best execution" to the municipal securities market. It requires dealers, when executing a transaction for a customer, to use reasonable diligence to ascertain the most favorable price under prevailing market conditions.
Impact: Established a key investor protection standard in the municipal market that was longstanding in the equity markets, enhancing the quality of transaction execution for investors in municipal bonds.

Regulation Title: Recordkeeping and Reporting Requirements for SecurityBased Swap Dealers
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted a comprehensive set of rules requiring securitybased swap dealers SBSDs to create and retain fundamental business records. It also requires SBSDs to make regular reports of their financial and operational condition to the SEC.
Impact: Established the core supervisory framework for SBSDs, allowing the SEC to monitor their activities, assess compliance, and conduct examinations to ensure market integrity and financial responsibility.

Regulation Title: FINRA Funding Portal Rules
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: Created a new, dedicated rulebook for SECregistered "funding portals," the intermediaries that operate online platforms for Regulation Crowdfunding offerings. The rules are more streamlined than the full FINRA rulebook for traditional brokers.
Impact: Established a tailored regulatory framework that made it feasible for these new types of financial intermediaries to operate, thereby enabling the entire equity crowdfunding ecosystem envisioned by the JOBS Act.

Regulation Title: Fixing America's Surface Transportation FAST Act
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: While primarily a transportation funding bill, the FAST Act contained a title with several capital formation provisions. It created a new exemption for private resales of securities Section 4a7 and allowed Emerging Growth Companies EGCs to omit certain historical financial information from their S1 registration statements.
Impact: Further streamlined the capitalraising process for smaller companies, building on the framework established by the JOBS Act to reduce disclosure and compliance burdens.

Regulation Title: Margin Requirements for Uncleared Swaps
Regulatory Body: Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC, FCA, FHFA, SEC, CFTC
Description: A set of joint rules that established minimum margin requirements for swaps that are not centrally cleared. The rules mandate the exchange of initial and variation margin between financial entities to collateralize the risk of these transactions.
Impact: A cornerstone of the G20/DoddFrank derivatives reforms, this rule significantly reduced counterparty credit risk in the uncleared swaps market, creating a strong incentive for central clearing.

Regulation Title: Regulation Crowdfunding
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Permitted individuals to invest in securitiesbased crowdfunding transactions subject to certain limits, as mandated by the JOBS Act.
Impact: Opened a new avenue for startups and small businesses to raise capital from a broad base of nonaccredited investors online.
Equity Issuance: Yes, Equity Issuance in Public vs. Private Markets

Regulation Title: Regulation of Funding Portals for Crowdfunding
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: As part of the Regulation Crowdfunding package, the SEC created a new, streamlined registration and regulatory framework for a new type of intermediary called a "funding portal." These webbased portals are exempt from full brokerdealer registration but are subject to specific rules tailored to their limited activities.
Impact: Created the necessary infrastructure for the retail crowdfunding market to exist by establishing a workable regulatory model for the platforms that connect issuers with investors.

Regulation Title: Pay Ratio Disclosure Rule
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required public companies to disclose the ratio of the median annual total compensation of all employees to the annual total compensation of the CEO.
Impact: Provided a new metric for investors and the public to assess executive compensation, sparking debate on income inequality.

Regulation Title: Registration and Regulation of SecurityBased Swap Dealers and Major Participants
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted rules under the DoddFrank Act that defined the terms "securitybased swap dealer" and "major securitybased swap participant" and established the process for these entities to register with the SEC.
Impact: Created the foundational framework for bringing regulatory oversight to the key dealers in the previously unregulated securitybased swap market, subjecting them to SEC supervision.

Regulation Title: Regulation A+
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Expanded Regulation A to allow smaller companies to offer and sell up to $50 million of securities in a 12month period, subject to eligibility and disclosure requirements.
Impact: Created a viable "miniIPO" pathway for smaller companies to raise capital from the public, including nonaccredited investors.
Equity Issuance: Yes, Equity Issuance in Public vs. Private Markets

Regulation Title: Tick Size Pilot Program
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: A twoyear pilot program, developed jointly by the national securities exchanges, to study the impact of wider trading increments tick sizes on the liquidity and trading of smallercompany stocks. The program tested quoting and trading in $0.05 increments for certain stocks.
Impact: Generated a massive amount of data on market structure and trading behavior, providing regulators with empirical evidence to assess whether changes to tick sizes could improve market quality for smaller issuers.

Regulation Title: Regulation SBSRâ€”Reporting and Dissemination of SecurityBased Swap Information
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Created a framework for the reporting of securitybased swap data to registered securitybased swap data repositories SDRs and the public dissemination of transaction data.
Impact: Brought significant transparency to the previously opaque securitybased swaps market, allowing regulators and the public to monitor activity and risk.

Regulation Title: Registration Process for SecurityBased Swap Data Repositories
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Established the formal registration process and the duties and core principles for securitybased swap data repositories SDRs, the central entities created by DoddFrank to collect and maintain records of swap transactions.
Impact: Created the operational and regulatory foundation for SDRs, the key market infrastructure needed to bring transparency and regulatory oversight to the securitybased swap market.

Regulation Title: Regulation SCI Systems Compliance and Integrity
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Establishes a framework requiring key market participants such as exchanges, clearing agencies, and alternative trading systems to ensure their technology systems are robust, resilient, and secure. It mandates policies, procedures, testing, and notification to the SEC of system disruptions.
Impact: Strengthened the technological infrastructure of U.S. securities markets to reduce the frequency of systems issues and improve resilience when problems do occur.

Regulation Title: Credit Risk Retention Rule DoddFrank Section 941
Regulatory Body: SEC, Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC, FHFA, HUD
Description: A joint rule requiring sponsors of assetbacked securities ABS to retain at least 5 percent of the credit risk of the assets they securitize. This "skin in the game" requirement is designed to align the interests of securitizers with those of investors.
Impact: Fundamentally changed the economics of securitization by forcing originators to maintain exposure to the loans they package and sell, discouraging the "originatetodistribute" model blamed for poor underwriting before the 2008 crisis.

Regulation Title: AssetBacked Securities Disclosure and Registration Regulation AB II
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Substantially revised the registration, disclosure, and reporting requirements for assetbacked securities ABS.
Impact: Increased transparency for investors in ABS by requiring detailed, assetlevel data about the securities' underlying collateral.

Regulation Title: CrossBorder SecurityBased Swap Activities
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: A major rule that established which crossborder securitybased swap transactions, and which entities engaging in them, would be subject to the registration and other requirements of the DoddFrank Act.
Impact: Defined the international scope and reach of U.S. derivatives regulation, a critical step for integrating the global swap markets into the new regulatory framework.

Regulation Title: FINRA Supervision Rules Rule 3110
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: A consolidated and modernized rule that requires member firms to establish and maintain a system to supervise the activities of their personnel. It includes specific requirements for supervisory procedures, internal inspections, and review of correspondence.
Impact: Created a comprehensive, principlesbased framework for brokerdealer supervision, enhancing firms' responsibility to monitor for and prevent misconduct by their employees.

Regulation Title: Volcker Rule
Regulatory Body: Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC, SEC, CFTC
Description: Prohibits banking entities from engaging in proprietary trading and limits their investments in hedge funds and private equity funds.
Impact: Aimed to reduce systemic risk by preventing federally insured banks from making speculative investments with their own capital.

Regulation Title: Eliminating the Prohibition Against General Solicitation Rule 506c
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: As mandated by the JOBS Act, lifted the ban on general solicitation and advertising for certain private offerings to accredited investors.
Impact: Made it easier for private companies and funds to raise capital by allowing them to publicly advertise their offerings.
Equity Issuance: Yes, Equity Issuance in Public vs. Private Markets

Regulation Title: FINRA Rule on Pledging of Customer Securities
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 4340, which prohibits member firms from rehypothecating pledging as collateral for the firm's own loans customer securities whose value exceeds 140% of the customer's debit balance. This aligns FINRA's rule with the SEC's Customer Protection Rule.
Impact: Strengthened the protection of customer assets by limiting the ability of brokerdealers to use customer securities for their own financing purposes, reducing risk to customers in the event of a firm's failure.

Regulation Title: CFTC Rules on Swap Execution Facilities SEFs
Regulatory Body: Commodity Futures Trading Commission CFTC
Description: A core rule of the DoddFrank Act that established the registration and oversight framework for Swap Execution Facilities SEFs. These are new trading platforms designed to bring transparency and competition to the overthecounter swaps market, requiring many standardized swaps to be traded on them.
Impact: Fundamentally changed the structure of the swaps market by moving a significant portion of trading from opaque, bilateral negotiations to transparent, regulated electronic platforms.

Regulation Title: Disclosure of Payments by Resource Extraction Issuers Section 1504 of DoddFrank
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires resource extraction issuers in oil, natural gas, or minerals to include in their annual report information relating to payments made to a foreign government or the U.S. Federal government for the purpose of commercial development.
Impact: Aims to increase the transparency of payments to governments to combat global corruption and empower citizens of resourcerich countries to hold their governments accountable. Note: This rule was subject to significant legal and political challenges and was reproposed and readopted over the years.

Regulation Title: Conflict Minerals Disclosure Rule
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required companies to disclose their use of certain minerals originating from the Democratic Republic of Congo or adjoining countries.
Impact: Aimed to reduce the funding of armed groups by increasing supply chain transparency, but faced legal challenges and high compliance costs.

Regulation Title: FINRA Suitability Rule Rule 2111
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: Codified and modernized the suitability obligation for brokerdealers. It requires a firm or associated person to have a reasonable basis to believe that a recommended transaction or investment strategy is suitable for the customer, based on the customer's investment profile.
Impact: Created a clear, uniform standard for suitability across the brokerage industry, serving as a key pillar of investor protection and a primary basis for customer arbitrations and enforcement actions.

Regulation Title: Consolidated Audit Trail CAT
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Mandated the creation of a single, comprehensive database to track all orders, cancellations, modifications, and trade executions for all U.S. equity and options securities across all U.S. markets.
Impact: Provides regulators with a powerful tool to surveil market activity, reconstruct market events, and detect manipulative or illegal trading behavior.

Regulation Title: Further Definition of "Swap," "SecurityBased Swap," and "SecurityBased Swap Agreement"
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC & Commodity Futures Trading Commission CFTC
Description: A joint foundational rule that defined the products that would be regulated by the SEC securitybased swaps, like singlename credit default swaps versus the CFTC swaps, like interest rate swaps.
Impact: Clarified regulatory jurisdiction over the vast overthecounter derivatives market, which was a critical first step in implementing the DoddFrank Act's comprehensive regulatory framework for swaps.

Regulation Title: FINRA Know Your Customer KYC Rule Rule 2090
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: A rule that requires brokerdealers to use "reasonable diligence" to know the "essential facts" concerning every customer. This includes understanding the customer's financial status, investment objectives, and risk tolerance to effectively service the account and comply with other rules like suitability.
Impact: Codified a foundational obligation for brokerdealers, serving as the bedrock for investor protection by ensuring that firms have the necessary information to handle customer accounts properly.

Regulation Title: Jumpstart Our Business Startups JOBS Act
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: Eased securities regulations to help smaller businesses raise capital, creating the "Emerging Growth Company" EGC category.
Impact: Reduced disclosure and compliance burdens for EGCs, making it easier for them to go public, and legalized equity crowdfunding.
Equity Issuance: Yes, Equity Issuance in Public vs. Private Markets

Regulation Title: JOBS Act  Raising the Registration and Deregistration Thresholds
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: As part of the JOBS Act, Section 12g of the Exchange Act was modified to raise the threshold that triggers public reporting requirements from 500 shareholders of record to either 2,000 shareholders of record, or 500 shareholders who are not accredited investors.
Impact: Allowed more companies to stay private for longer, reducing their compliance burdens and potentially increasing the vibrancy of private markets. It was a major change to the public vs. private company calculus.

Regulation Title: Clearing Agency Standards
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Established enhanced standards for the operation and governance of registered clearing agencies like DTCC, focusing on risk management, settlement, and default procedures as mandated by the DoddFrank Act.
Impact: Strengthened the resilience of critical market infrastructure to reduce the risk of systemic contagion in the financial system.

Regulation Title: FINRA Communications with the Public Rule 2210
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: A major rule consolidation that created a single, comprehensive rule governing brokerdealer communications with the public. It streamlined definitions, established principlesbased content standards, and set requirements for approval, recordkeeping, and filing with FINRA.
Impact: Modernized the rules for brokerdealer advertising and communications to address new technologies like social media, while maintaining core principles of fairness and balance.

Regulation Title: Mine Safety Disclosure Section 1503 of DoddFrank
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires domestic and foreign issuers that are mine operators to disclose in their periodic reports information regarding specified mine safety and health violations, orders, and citations received from the Mine Safety and Health Administration MSHA.
Impact: Increased transparency into mine safety records, allowing investors to better assess operational and regulatory risks associated with mining companies.

Regulation Title: Form PF: Reporting by Investment Advisers to Private Funds
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC & Commodity Futures Trading Commission CFTC
Description: A joint rule under the DoddFrank Act that requires advisers to certain private funds e.g., hedge funds, private equity funds to periodically file a confidential Form PF, reporting detailed information about their funds' strategies, assets, leverage, and risk exposures.
Impact: Provided financial regulators, particularly the Financial Stability Oversight Council FSOC, with crucial data to monitor and assess systemic risk in the previously opaque private funds industry.

Regulation Title: Resolution Plans "Living Wills" DoddFrank Section 165d
Regulatory Body: Federal Reserve & Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation FDIC
Description: Requires large, complex financial institutions including those with significant securities operations to periodically submit detailed resolution plans, or "living wills." These plans must describe the company's strategy for a rapid and orderly resolution in the event of material financial distress or failure.
Impact: Forced the largest financial firms to confront their own complexity and develop credible strategies for being dismantled without causing systemic chaos, enhancing both internal risk management and regulatory preparedness.

Regulation Title: Whistleblower Incentives and Protection CFTC Program
Regulatory Body: Commodity Futures Trading Commission CFTC
Description: As mandated by the DoddFrank Act, the CFTC established its own whistleblower program, similar to the SEC's. It provides monetary awards and antiretaliation protections to individuals who report violations of the Commodity Exchange Act.
Impact: Created a powerful new enforcement tool for policing the futures and swaps markets, leading to a significant increase in tips and major enforcement actions related to manipulation and fraud in these markets.

Regulation Title: Registration of Municipal Advisors
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented a DoddFrank provision creating a registration regime for municipal advisors, who advise state and local governments on issuing municipal securities and other financial matters.
Impact: Brought federal oversight to a previously unregulated group of market participants, aiming to protect municipalities from conflicted or improper advice.

Regulation Title: Large Trader Reporting Rule Rule 13h1
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires large traders who engage in a substantial level of trading activity to identify themselves to the SEC by filing Form 13H. They receive a unique Large Trader ID LTID which they must provide to their brokerdealers, who in turn must report trading data for those LTIDs to the SEC.
Impact: Enhances the SEC's ability to identify and obtain trading information on the most significant market participants, allowing for more effective investigation of manipulative behavior and analysis of market events.

Regulation Title: Exemptions for Advisers to Venture Capital Funds and Others DoddFrank Act
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented DoddFrank provisions that required most advisers to private funds like hedge funds to register with the SEC, but created specific exemptions for advisers who solely manage venture capital funds or have less than $150 million in private fund assets under management in the U.S.
Impact: Significantly expanded SEC oversight to the private fund industry while tailoring regulations to avoid unduly burdening smaller advisers and venture capital firms.

Regulation Title: IncentiveBased Compensation Arrangements Section 956 of DoddFrank
Regulatory Body: SEC, OCC, Federal Reserve, FDIC, NCUA, FHFA
Description: Proposed joint rules requiring enhanced disclosure and oversight of incentivebased compensation practices at large financial institutions to ensure that these structures do not encourage inappropriate risktaking.
Impact: Although a final rule has been repeatedly delayed, the proposal itself has significantly influenced how financial institutions design and govern executive compensation to better align with longterm risk management.

Regulation Title: Whistleblower Program Rules Section 922 of DoddFrank
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Established a program to reward individuals who provide original information about securities violations that leads to successful enforcement actions.
Impact: Created powerful incentives for insiders to report fraud, significantly increasing the number and quality of tips received by the SEC.

Regulation Title: Whistleblower AntiRetaliation Protections DoddFrank Section 922
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: In addition to creating the award program, the SEC's whistleblower rules implemented strong antiretaliation provisions. These created a private right of action for whistleblowers who are fired, demoted, or otherwise discriminated against for providing information to the SEC.
Impact: Provided critical job protection for individuals who report potential securities fraud, encouraging more insiders to come forward without fear of reprisal.

Regulation Title: SayonPay and Golden Parachute Rules
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented DoddFrank provisions requiring companies to hold nonbinding shareholder advisory votes on executive compensation.
Impact: Empowered shareholders with a voice on executive pay, increasing board accountability and scrutiny of compensation practices.

Regulation Title: Issuer Review of Assets in Offerings of AssetBacked Securities
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 193 under the Securities Act, as mandated by the DoddFrank Act. The rule requires an issuer of assetbacked securities ABS to perform a review of the assets underlying the ABS and disclose the nature of that review.
Impact: Increased accountability in the securitization process by ensuring that the issuer examines the quality of the underlying loans, aiming to prevent the "garbage in, garbage out" problem seen in the 2008 financial crisis.

Regulation Title: FINRA Rules on Outside Business Activities and Private Securities Transactions
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: A set of rules 3270 and 3280 that require registered persons to provide written notice to their firms before engaging in outside business activities or participating in any private securities transactions socalled "selling away".
Impact: Provides firms with critical tools to supervise the outside activities of their brokers, aiming to prevent conflicts of interest and unapproved, potentially fraudulent, securities sales.

Regulation Title: Facilitating Shareholder Director Nominations Proxy Access
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 14a11, which would have required public companies to include the director nominees of certain longterm shareholders in their proxy materials. Note: The rule was subsequently vacated by the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals in 2011 and never took effect, but its adoption was a major regulatory event.
Impact: Though vacated, the rule spurred a widespread movement where companies voluntarily adopted proxy access bylaws through shareholder proposals, fundamentally changing the landscape of director elections.

Regulation Title: Orderly Liquidation Authority DoddFrank Act Title II
Regulatory Body: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation FDIC / U.S. Treasury
Description: Created a new resolution regime, managed by the FDIC, to liquidate large, complex financial companies including major brokerdealers or their parent companies whose failure could pose a systemic risk to the U.S. economy. It is an alternative to the bankruptcy code.
Impact: Provided the government with a mechanism to wind down a failing "too big to fail" financial firm in a controlled manner, aiming to prevent the chaotic collapse and taxpayer bailouts seen during the 2008 crisis.

Regulation Title: DoddFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: A comprehensive reform of U.S. financial regulation in response to the 2008 financial crisis. Created numerous new rules and agencies.
Impact: Reshaped the financial industry by increasing capital requirements, regulating derivatives, and creating consumer protections.
Equity Issuance: Yes, Equity Issuance in Public vs. Private Markets

Regulation Title: Financial Stability Oversight Council FSOC Designation Authority
Regulatory Body: Financial Stability Oversight Council FSOC
Description: Created by Title I of the DoddFrank Act, the FSOC is a council of U.S. financial regulators. It was given the new authority to designate certain nonbank financial companies such as large asset managers or insurance firms as "systemically important financial institutions" SIFIs, subjecting them to enhanced supervision by the Federal Reserve.
Impact: Extended prudential, banklike supervision beyond traditional banks to other types of financial firms whose failure could threaten the stability of the financial system.

Regulation Title: Extraterritorial Jurisdiction of the Antifraud Provisions DoddFrank Section 929P
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: A statutory provision in the DoddFrank Act that explicitly grants U.S. federal courts jurisdiction over SEC enforcement actions involving fraudulent conduct that has a "foreseeable substantial effect" within the U.S., or conduct within the U.S. that is significant to the fraud, even if the transactions or victims are outside the U.S.
Impact: Partially overturned the Supreme Court's *Morrison v. National Australia Bank* decision, restoring and clarifying the SEC's ability to police international securities fraud that has a connection to the United States.

Regulation Title: Custody of Funds or Securities of Clients by Investment Advisers
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Substantially strengthened the custody rule Rule 20642 for investment advisers in the wake of the Madoff fraud. The new framework required advisers with custody to undergo an annual surprise examination by an independent accountant to verify client assets.
Impact: Enhanced the protection of client assets managed by investment advisers by adding a critical layer of thirdparty verification, making it much more difficult to misappropriate funds.

Regulation Title: Proxy Disclosure Enhancements
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required enhanced disclosure regarding compensation, director qualifications, board leadership structure, and the board's role in risk oversight.
Impact: Provided investors with more detailed information to evaluate board composition, executive pay, and corporate risk management.

Regulation Title: MSRB Advertising Rule Modernization Rule G21
Regulatory Body: Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board MSRB / Approved by SEC
Description: A major update to the rule governing municipal securities advertising to address modern communication methods. It clarified that "advertisement" includes electronic communications, websites, and emails, and it requires all advertisements to be fair, balanced, and not misleading.
Impact: Modernized the standards for how municipal bond dealers communicate with the public, ensuring that investor protections keep pace with evolving technology.

Regulation Title: Mandate for Interactive Data XBRL in Filings
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Phased in a requirement for public companies to provide their financial statements in an interactive data format using eXtensible Business Reporting Language XBRL. This provides a machinereadable layer on top of traditional financial reports.
Impact: Transformed financial data from static, textbased documents into structured, searchable data, making it easier for investors and analysts to extract, compare, and analyze financial information.

Regulation Title: Regulation SID Identity Theft Red Flags Rule
Regulatory Body: SEC, CFTC, Federal Trade Commission, Banking Regulators
Description: A joint rule implementing the Fair Credit Reporting Act that requires financial institutions and creditors, including many SECregistered entities like brokerdealers and mutual funds, to develop and implement a written Identity Theft Prevention Program to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft.
Impact: Made identity theft prevention a formal compliance responsibility for securities firms, requiring them to actively monitor customer accounts for red flags indicating potential fraud.

Regulation Title: Rules for Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organizations NRSROs
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented the Credit Rating Agency Reform Act of 2006 by establishing a registration and oversight program for credit rating agencies. The rules set requirements for preventing conflicts of interest, prohibiting unfair practices, and disclosing rating methodologies.
Impact: Brought formal federal oversight to the credit rating industry for the first time, aiming to improve the quality, transparency, and accountability of credit ratings.

Regulation Title: Internet Availability of Proxy Materials
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Allows companies to satisfy proxy delivery requirements by posting materials online and providing shareholders with a notice.
Impact: Reduced printing and mailing costs for companies and provided shareholders with faster, more convenient access to information.

Regulation Title: Credit Rating Agency Reform Act of 2006
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: Created a new registration and oversight program for credit rating agencies, requiring the SEC to regulate them as Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organizations NRSROs.
Impact: Aimed to improve the quality and transparency of credit ratings, though its effectiveness was questioned after the 2008 crisis.

Regulation Title: SEC Interpretation on "Soft Dollar" Arrangements Section 28e
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Issued a major interpretive release that significantly narrowed the scope of "brokerage and research services" that can be obtained by investment managers using client commission dollars "soft dollars" under the safe harbor of Section 28e. It clarified that services must have a direct link to the investment decisionmaking process.
Impact: Imposed greater discipline on the use of soft dollars by money managers, forcing them to justify that payments were for legitimate research that benefits clients, rather than for overhead or other nonresearch expenses.

Regulation Title: Securities Offering Reform
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: A major overhaul of the registration, communication, and offering processes for public securities offerings under the Securities Act of 1933. It created a new category of issuer, the "WellKnown Seasoned Issuer" WKSI, with greater flexibility in communicating and launching offerings.
Impact: Modernized the capitalraising process for public companies, making it more efficient and flexible, particularly for larger, more established issuers. It liberalized rules on communications around the time of an offering.

Regulation Title: Certain BrokerDealers Deemed Not To Be Investment Advisers
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted a rule that exempted brokerdealers offering feebased brokerage accounts from the Investment Advisers Act, provided they provided no special advice and made prominent disclosure. The rule was highly controversial and was ultimately vacated by a federal court in 2007.
Impact: Though shortlived, the rule was a major event in the longrunning debate over the differing regulatory standards for brokers and investment advisers, and its vacatur ultimately led to the development of Regulation Best Interest.

Regulation Title: Regulation NMS National Market System
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: A set of rules designed to modernize and strengthen the national market system for equity securities. Key provisions include the "Order Protection Rule" or tradethrough rule which prevents the execution of trades at prices inferior to protected quotations displayed by other trading centers.
Impact: Fundamentally reshaped U.S. equity market structure by promoting competition among trading venues and ensuring investors receive the best price across markets, but also increased market complexity.

Regulation Title: Rule 22c2 Redemption Fees
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Authorized mutual funds to impose a redemption fee of up to 2% on the proceeds from shares redeemed within a short period of time. It also required funds to enter into informationsharing agreements with financial intermediaries to obtain trading data.
Impact: Provided funds with a tool to deter harmful shortterm trading and market timing, and enabled them to better monitor trading activity through omnibus accounts.

Regulation Title: Disclosure Regarding Nominating Committee Functions and Communications Between Security Holders and Boards of Directors
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required companies to disclose information about their board nominating committees, including their processes for identifying and evaluating director candidates, and whether they consider candidates recommended by shareholders.
Impact: Provided investors with greater insight into the director nomination process, promoting transparency and accountability in corporate governance.

Regulation Title: Regulation SHO
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Created a new framework for regulating short sales, including "locate" and "closeout" requirements to curb "naked" short selling.
Impact: Aimed to reduce failures to deliver securities and combat potentially abusive short selling practices.

Regulation Title: Disclosure of Breakpoint Sales and Point of Sale Disclosure
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required mutual funds to provide enhanced, plainEnglish disclosure in their prospectuses about "breakpoint" discounts on frontend sales loads for Class A shares, helping investors understand how to qualify for volume discounts.
Impact: Aimed to ensure that investors receive the sales charge discounts they are entitled to when making large purchases of mutual fund shares.

Regulation Title: Investment Company Codes of Ethics
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted a new rule and amendments requiring mutual funds to have codes of ethics that set standards of conduct and address conflicts of interest from personal trading by fund employees. It also enhanced the reporting of personal securities transactions by these employees.
Impact: Strengthened the ethical framework governing mutual fund personnel to prevent fraudulent and abusive personal trading practices, such as frontrunning the fund's trades.

Regulation Title: FINRA Rules on IPO Allocations Rule 5130 & 5131
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: A set of rules designed to ensure fairness in the allocation of new issues. Rule 5130 prohibits firms from selling "new issues" to accounts in which a restricted person has a beneficial interest. Rule 5131 prohibits abusive allocation practices like "spinning" allocating IPO shares to executives to win investment banking business.
Impact: Aims to protect the integrity of the IPO process by preventing industry insiders from taking advantage of their positions and ensuring that shares are offered to the public fairly.

Regulation Title: Additional Form 8K Disclosure Requirements and Acceleration of Filing Date
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: In response to SOX's call for "realtime" disclosures, this rule significantly expanded the number of events that must be reported on Form 8K the "current report" and shortened the filing deadline to four business days for most items.
Impact: Provided investors with more timely access to a broader range of material information about public companies, reducing the information gap between corporate insiders and the public.

Regulation Title: Compliance Programs of Investment Companies and Investment Advisers
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 20647, which requires every SECregistered investment adviser to adopt and implement written policies and procedures reasonably designed to prevent violation of the federal securities laws, review them annually for adequacy, and designate a chief compliance officer CCO.
Impact: Professionalized and formalized the compliance function within the asset management industry, making compliance a core responsibility of every advisory firm.

Regulation Title: Management's Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting SOX 404
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires management to assess and report on the effectiveness of the company's internal controls over financial reporting.
Impact: Significantly increased focus and spending on internal controls, aiming to improve the reliability of financial statements.

Regulation Title: Mandated Electronic Filing and Website Posting for Forms 3, 4 and 5 SOX 403
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required corporate insiders directors, officers, and 10% owners to file their reports of stock ownership and transactions Forms 3, 4, and 5 electronically through the SEC's EDGAR system. It also required companies to post these reports on their corporate websites.
Impact: Drastically accelerated the public availability of information about insider trading activity, moving from a slow, paperbased system to near realtime electronic access for all investors.

Regulation Title: Public Company Accounting Oversight Board PCAOB Establishment
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Pursuant to Title I of the SarbanesOxley Act, this action formally recognized the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board PCAOB. The PCAOB is a private, nonprofit corporation established by Congress to oversee the audits of public companies in order to protect investors.
Impact: Fundamentally changed the landscape of accounting regulation by ending the profession's selfregulation. The PCAOB now sets auditing standards, inspects accounting firms, and enforces rules, significantly increasing the quality and independence of public company audits.

Regulation Title: Improper Influence on Conduct of Audits SOX 303
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 13b22b, which explicitly prohibits officers and directors of an issuer from taking any action to fraudulently influence, coerce, manipulate, or mislead the independent auditor of the company's financial statements for the purpose of rendering those statements materially misleading.
Impact: Provided the SEC with a direct enforcement tool to sanction corporate insiders who improperly pressure auditors, thereby reinforcing auditor independence and the integrity of the audit process.

Regulation Title: Standards Relating to Listed Company Audit Committees SOX 301
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Directed the national securities exchanges to prohibit the listing of any security of an issuer that is not in compliance with the audit committee requirements established by the SarbanesOxley Act. These include committee independence and direct responsibility for the appointment, compensation, and oversight of the external auditor.
Impact: Strengthened the oversight of the financial reporting process by empowering independent audit committees as the primary client of the external auditor, reducing management's influence.

Regulation Title: Regulation AC Analyst Certification
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires research analysts to certify that the views expressed in their research reports accurately reflect their personal views.
Impact: Aimed to improve the objectivity of research and reduce conflicts of interest between research and investment banking departments.

Regulation Title: Proxy Voting by Investment Advisers
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Adopted Rule 20646, which requires an investment adviser that exercises voting authority over client securities to adopt and implement policies and procedures that are reasonably designed to ensure that the adviser votes proxies in the best interest of its clients.
Impact: Increased the transparency and accountability of the proxy voting process by advisers, ensuring they manage voting, a key client asset, with the same fiduciary care as other assets.

Regulation Title: Shareholder Reports and Quarterly Portfolio Disclosure of Registered Management Investment Companies
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Required mutual funds to disclose their complete portfolio holdings on a quarterly basis, rather than semiannually. It also required funds to include a statement in their annual reports specifying how they voted proxies relating to their portfolio securities.
Impact: Significantly increased the transparency of mutual fund holdings and proxy voting behavior, allowing investors and analysts to better monitor fund strategies and governance activities.

Regulation Title: Insider Trades During Pension Fund Blackout Periods SOX 306
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented Regulation BTR, which prohibits any director or executive officer of an issuer from purchasing or selling company equity during a "blackout period" when at least 50% of the participants in the company's retirement plans are temporarily suspended from trading.
Impact: Promoted fairness by preventing corporate insiders from trading when rankandfile employees are unable to, particularly during administrative transitions in pension plans.

Regulation Title: Strengthening the Commission's Requirements Regarding Auditor Independence SOX Title II
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Implemented Title II of the SarbanesOxley Act by defining and prohibiting a list of nonaudit services that accounting firms are barred from providing to their audit clients e.g., bookkeeping, internal audit outsourcing, legal services. It also mandated audit partner rotation.
Impact: Enhanced auditor independence by minimizing economic incentives and conflicts of interest that could compromise audit integrity. This forced a major restructuring of the business models of the large accounting firms.

Regulation Title: Standards of Professional Conduct for Attorneys
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires attorneys appearing before the SEC to report evidence of a material violation of securities law "up the ladder" within the company.
Impact: Placed new ethical and reporting obligations on lawyers, making them gatekeepers for corporate compliance SOX Section 307.

Regulation Title: Disclosure of OffBalance Sheet Arrangements
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Mandates disclosure of offbalance sheet arrangements in a separately captioned subsection of the MD&A SOX Section 401.
Impact: Increased transparency into complex financial structures that companies like Enron used to hide debt and inflate earnings.

Regulation Title: Conditions for Use of NonGAAP Financial Measures
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Established rules Regulation G for the public disclosure of financial information calculated on a nonGAAP basis.
Impact: Required companies to reconcile nonGAAP measures to their most comparable GAAP measure, preventing misleading presentations.

Regulation Title: Disclosure of Audit Committee Financial Expert SOX 407
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires public companies to disclose in their annual reports whether their audit committee includes at least one member who is an "audit committee financial expert," and if not, the reasons why. The rule defines the attributes of such an expert.
Impact: Strengthened the financial oversight capabilities of boards by encouraging companies to appoint individuals with significant financial and accounting expertise to their audit committees.

Regulation Title: Disclosure Required by Sections 406 and 407 of the SarbanesOxley Act of 2002
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: This rule requires a public company to disclose whether it has adopted a code of ethics that applies to its principal executive officer, principal financial officer, and other senior financial officers. Any waivers of the code for these officers must also be disclosed.
Impact: Promoted ethical conduct at the highest levels of corporate management by using disclosure to encourage the adoption and enforcement of strong ethical standards.

Regulation Title: Exemption for Standardized Options from Provisions of the Securities Act Rule 238
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Exempted standardized options that are issued by a registered clearing agency and traded on a national securities exchange from all provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, other than the antifraud provisions. The disclosure framework is instead provided by the Options Clearing Corporation's disclosure document.
Impact: Streamlined the regulatory treatment of standardized options, recognizing their unique nature and the central role of the options exchanges and clearinghouse in providing disclosure and market integrity.

Regulation Title: Certification of Disclosure in Companies' Quarterly and Annual Reports SOX 302
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
Description: Requires the principal executive officer and principal financial officer of a public company to personally certify the accuracy of their company's quarterly and annual reports. They must also certify that they are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures.
Impact: Dramatically increased the personal accountability of senior executives for the accuracy of financial statements and disclosures, serving as a powerful deterrent to fraud.

Regulation Title: Rules for Security Futures Products
Regulatory Body: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission SEC & Commodity Futures Trading Commission CFTC
Description: A set of joint rules establishing the regulatory framework for security futuresâ€”new hybrid products created by the Commodity Futures Modernization Act of 2000. The rules covered customer protection, recordkeeping, and margin requirements.
Impact: Created the legal and operational infrastructure for the trading of futures on single stocks and narrowbased stock indexes, bridging the gap between securities and futures regulation.

Regulation Title: Fair Funds for Investors SOX 308
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress within the SarbanesOxley Act
Description: Authorized the SEC to take civil penalties obtained in enforcement actions and add them to a disgorgement fund a "Fair Fund" to be distributed to victims of the securities law violations. Previously, penalties were paid to the U.S. Treasury.
Impact: Significantly increased the amount of money returned to harmed investors from SEC enforcement actions, making it a primary goal of the enforcement program to compensate victims.

Regulation Title: SarbanesOxley Act of 2002 SOX
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress
Description: Established new standards for public company boards, management, and accounting firms in response to major accounting scandals.
Impact: Increased compliance costs but improved investor confidence through enhanced corporate governance and financial disclosures.

Regulation Title: Prohibition of Company Personal Loans to Executives SOX 402
Regulatory Body: U.S. Congress within the SarbanesOxley Act
Description: Made it unlawful for any public company to directly or indirectly extend or maintain credit, or arrange for the extension of credit, in the form of a personal loan to or for any director or executive officer.
Impact: Ended a common corporate practice that was viewed as a potential source of conflicts of interest and selfdealing, thereby strengthening corporate governance standards.

Regulation Title: FINRA Research Analyst Conflict of Interest Rules
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: A comprehensive set of new rules initially NASD Rule 2711 and NYSE Rule 472 designed to separate research analyst compensation from investment banking business, prohibit analysts from being supervised by investment bankers, and require clear disclosure of conflicts in research reports.
Impact: Fundamentally restructured the relationship between research and investment banking departments at Wall Street firms to restore public confidence in the objectivity of research following the dotcom bubble scandals.

Regulation Title: FINRA AntiMoney Laundering AML Program Rule Rule 3310
Regulatory Body: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority FINRA / Approved by SEC
Description: This rule requires member firms to establish and implement an AntiMoney Laundering AML compliance program, as required by the Bank Secrecy Act. The program must include policies, procedures, a designated AML compliance person, ongoing training, and independent testing.
Impact: Made brokerdealers a key part of the U.S. government's effort to combat money laundering and terrorist financing by requiring them to actively monitor for and report suspicious activity.
